title:
Mild ill-posedness in $W^{1,\infty}$ for the incompressible porous media
  equation

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper, we establish the mild ill-posedness of 2D IPM equation in the critical Sobolev space $W^{1, \infty}$ when the initial data are small perturbations of stable profile $g\left(x_{2}\right)$. Consequently, instability can be inferred. Notably, our results are valid for arbitrary vertically stratified density profiles $g\left(x_{2}\right)$ without imposing any restrictions on the sign of $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)$. From a physical perspective, since gravity acts downward, density profiles satisfying $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)<0$ typically correspond to stable configurations, whereas those with $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)>0$ are generally expected to be unstable.Surprisingly, our analysis uncovers an unexpected instability even when $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)<0$ and $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \in W^{2, \infty}(\mathbb{R})$. To the best of our knowledge, this work provides the first rigorous demonstration of IPM instability for vertically nonlinear density profiles, marking a significant departure from conventional physical expectations.


MSC(2020): 76S05, 35R25, 76B70
Keywords: The incompressible porous media equation, Ill-posedness, Instability

## 1 Introduction

In this paper, we consider the 2D incompressible porous medium (IPM) system, which consists of an active scalar equation with a velocity field $u(\mathbf{x}, t)$ satisfying the momentum equation given by Darcy's law. That is,

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\partial_{t} \rho+(u \cdot \nabla) \rho=0 \\
u=-\nabla p-(0, \rho) \\
\nabla \cdot u=0 \\
\rho(\mathbf{x}, 0)=\rho_{0}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $(\mathbf{x}, t) \in \mathbb{R}^{2} \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$with $\mathbf{x}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right), \rho(\mathbf{x}, t)$ represents the density transported by the fluid, $u(\mathbf{x}, t)$ is the incompressible velocity, and $p(\mathbf{x}, t)$ is the pressure. We refer to $[7,18]$ and references therein for further explanations on the physical background and applications of this model.

By utilizing the incompressibility condition, the Biot-Savart law for the velocity field of 2D IPM equation can be expressed as either

$$
u=\nabla^{\perp}(-\Delta)^{-1} \partial_{x_{1}} \rho \text { or } u=\nabla^{\perp}(-\Delta)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathcal{R}_{1} \rho
$$

where $\mathcal{R}_{1}$ represents the first component of the Riesz transform. As a result, the regularity of the velocity in system (1.1) is the same as that of the 2D SQG equation but is one order lower than that of the 2D Euler equation. Additionally, a notable distinction is that the Biot-Savart law of the 2D IPM equation contains a horizontal partial derivatives $\partial_{x_{1}}$. This feature leads to the existence of relatively simple steadystate solutions of the form $\rho_{s}(x)=g\left(x_{2}\right)$.

Let us denote $\eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \rho(\mathbf{x}, t)-g\left(x_{2}\right)$, where $\rho(\mathbf{x}, t)$ is the solution of system (1.1), then $\eta$ satisfies the following perturbation equation:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\partial_{t} \eta+(u \cdot \nabla) \eta=-g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta \\
u=\nabla^{\perp}(-\Delta)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathcal{R}_{1} \eta \\
\eta(\mathbf{x}, 0)=\eta_{0}(\mathbf{x})=\rho_{0}(\mathbf{x})-g\left(x_{2}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Here, $\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}$ on the right-hand side of the perturbation equation is a negative operator. If $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)<0$ (which physically corresponds to a fluid density that varies only in the vertical direction, with the density of each upper layer being less than that of the lower layer, indicating a stably stratified fluid), then the stability of the perturbation equation can be expected.

Well-posedness The 2D IPM equation is locally well-posed in $H^{s}(X)(s>2)$, where $X$ can be the whole space $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, a periodic domain $\mathbb{T}^{2}$, or a bounded strip domain $\mathbb{S}=\mathbb{T} \times[-l, l], 0<l<\infty$, as seen in references [7], [30] and [21]. However, the global well-posedness remains a challenging and unresolved problem, similarly to the SQG equation case.

In recent years, significant progress has been made regarding the global wellposedness of system (1.1) for initial data close to linear stratified density $g\left(x_{2}\right)=-x_{2}$ in certain Sobolev spaces, which also implies the asymptotic stability of system (1.2), see $[2,7,14,20,27]$. Elgindi [14] established the asymptotic stability of system (1.2) for initial perturbations in $H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right) \cap W^{4,1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and $H^{k}\left(\mathbb{T}^{2}\right)$ with $k \geq 20$. Recently, Bianchini, Crin-Barat and Paicu improved this result in [2] by assuming the initial perturbations belonging to $\dot{H}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right) \cap \dot{H}^{\tau}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ with $0<\tau<1, s \geq 3+\tau$. For the case of the flat strip $\mathbb{S}=\mathbb{T} \times[-l, l]$ with $0<l<\infty$, the stability of the stratified steady state solutions was proved in [7] under the condition $\left\|\rho_{0}-g\left(x_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}(\mathbb{S})} \leq \varepsilon$ with $k \geq 10$. More recently, this result was refined in [27] under slightly less restrictive regularity assumptions, requiring only $\left\|\rho_{0}-g\left(x_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}(\mathbb{S})} \leq \varepsilon$ with $k \geq 3$. Additionally,

we highlight the work in [20], which establishes asymptotic stability in the torus $\mathbb{T}^{2}$, or the strip $\mathbb{S}$, or the whole space $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ for a perturbation in $H^{k}$ for $k>3$, provided that the vertical derivative of the steady state $g\left(x_{2}\right)$ is sufficiently large, depending on the size of the perturbation. It is also noteworthy that Kiselev and Yao [21] constructed examples of solutions exhibiting infinite growth of derivatives over time, demonstrating nonlinear instability for a class of stratified steady states of the IPM equation on $\mathbb{T}^{2}$ and $\mathbb{S}$.

Ill-posedness Since the pioneering work by Bourgain and Li on the strong illposedness of the Euler equations in critical spaces ([4]), there have been many remarkable results regarding ill-posedness of the Euler equations (see $[5,6,15,16,22,25]$ ) and SQG equations (see $[8,12,13,19]$ ). Given the similarities between the SQG and IPM equations, particularly the same order of their Biot-Savart laws, it is natural to conjecture that analogous ill-posedness results may hold for the IPM equations. However, the notable differences in symmetry and anisotropy between the two systems make the ill-posedness problem of the 2D IPM equations a non-trivial challenge. Recently, Bianchini et al. [3] posted an article on the arXiv with a significant strong ill-posedness result in critical space $H^{2}$ near the linear stratified steady state $g\left(x_{2}\right)=-x_{2}$.

The goal of this paper is to establish the ill-posedness result for perturbations of a more general stable profile $g\left(x_{2}\right)$. Specifically, we construct solutions that are initially in the space of compactly supported, infinitely differentiable functions $C_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and small in the critical Sobolev space $W^{1, \infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$, but the solutions become large in $W^{1, \infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ within a short period of time. Our main result can be summarized stated as follows.

Theorem 1.1. Let $g\left(x_{2}\right)$ be any horizontal stratified state satisfying $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \not \equiv 0$ and $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \in W^{2, \infty}(\mathbb{R})$. For every sufficiently small $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a initial data $\eta_{0}(\mathbf{x}) \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ satisfying

$$
\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{W^{1, \infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)} \leq \varepsilon
$$

such that the unique local solution $\eta(\cdot, t)$ of system (1.2) with initial data $\eta_{0}$ satisfies

$$
\sup _{0 \leq t \leq \tilde{c} \varepsilon}\|\eta(\cdot, t)\|_{W^{1, \infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)} \geq \tilde{C}
$$

Here, $\tilde{c}, \tilde{C}$ are universal constants that are independent of $\varepsilon$ but depend on the choice of $g\left(x_{2}\right)$.

Remark 1.1. In contrast to the work by Bianchini et al. [3], which established the strong ill-posedness of the IPM equation for initial data that are small $H^{2}$ perturbations of the linearly stable profile $-x_{2}$, our work demonstrates mild ill-posedness in the critical space $W^{1, \infty}$ (For detailed definitions of strong and mild ill-posedness, readers are referred to [4] and [16]).

Remark 1.2. We emphasize that our result holds for arbitrary vertically stratified density profiles $g\left(x_{2}\right)$, with no assumptions required on the sign of $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)$. Physically,

since gravity acts downward, density profiles with $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)<0$ typically represent stable configurations (density decreasing with height), while those with $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)>0$ normally correspond to unstable scenarios. Remarkably, our analysis uncovers a surprising instability mechanism that persists even when $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)<0$ and $g^{\prime} \in W^{2, \infty}(\mathbb{R})$. To the best of our knowledge, this constitutes the first rigorous demonstration of ill-posedness for the IPM equation with nonlinear vertical density stratification.

Ideas of proof The main idea demonstrated in this paper can be summarized in the following three steps:

# Step 1. Provide two local prior bounds 

Assume that $\eta \in L^{\infty}\left(0, T ; B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)\right)$ for some $T>0$ is a solution of system (1.2) corresponding to the initial value $\eta_{0} \in B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ with $2<p<\infty$, then, for $t \in[0, T]$,

$$
\|\eta(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}} \leq \frac{\frac{c_{g}}{2}+2\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}}}{1-C\left(\frac{c_{g}}{2}+2\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}}\right) t}
$$

and

$$
\|\eta(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \leq\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \mathrm{e}^{c_{t}\left(\sup _{0 \leq s \leq t}\|\eta(s)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}}+c_{g}\right)}
$$

where $c_{g}$ is a fixed constant characterizing the background stratification.

## Step 2. Construction of the right initial data

Inspired by the work of Elgindi and Masmoudi on the logarithmic singularity of Riesz operators [16], we introduce a novel weighted estimation method for general steady states (where $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)$ is not identically zero). This approach preserves the delicate balance required for singularity analysis while effectively capturing nontrivial stratification effects.

To establish a lower bound on $\|\nabla \eta\|_{L^{\infty}}$, it is essential to construct initial data that not only induces growth at $t=0$, but also ensures that the nonlinear evolution does not suppress this growth mechanism for $t>0$. Specifically, we design the initial data for system (1.2) as follows:

$$
\eta_{0}(\mathbf{x})=\rho_{0}(\mathbf{x})-g\left(x_{2}\right)=\frac{f_{N}(\mathbf{x})}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

where

$$
f_{N}(\mathbf{x})=\partial_{x_{1}} \Delta\left(G_{N}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{0}}\right) \chi\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{0}}\right)\right)
$$

$$
G_{N}(\mathbf{x})=\left(x_{1}^{3} x_{2}-x_{1} x_{2}^{3}\right) \log \left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2^{N}}\right)
$$

Here, the point $\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{0}}=\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is selected to satisfy $g^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{0}}\right)=g^{\prime}\left(y_{0}\right) \neq 0$, and $\chi(\mathbf{x})$ is a smooth cut-off function

$$
\chi(\mathbf{x})= \begin{cases}1, & \text { on } B(\mathbf{0} ; 1)=\left\{\mathbf{x}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) ;|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{0}| \leq 1\right\} \\ 0, & \text { on } B(\mathbf{0} ; 2)^{c}=\left\{\mathbf{x}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) ;|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{0}|>2\right\}\end{cases}
$$

After careful verification, for $\forall i, j, k, l \in\{1,2\}$, we conclude that from a degree point of view,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \partial_{i} \Delta G_{N}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \approx\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2^{N}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \partial_{i} \partial_{j} \Delta G_{N}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \approx 1 \\
& \partial_{i} \partial_{j} \partial_{k} \Delta G_{N}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \approx \frac{1}{\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2^{N}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}} \\
& \partial_{i} \partial_{j} \partial_{k} \partial_{l} \Delta G_{N}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \approx \frac{1}{x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2^{N}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\partial_{i}=\partial_{x_{i}}$. However, if $\Delta$ is not applied to $G_{N}$, and $\partial_{1}^{2}$ is applied, then logarithmic singularity will appear. In fact, $\partial_{1}^{2}$ is equal to $-\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \Delta$, so we have

$$
\partial_{1}^{3} \partial_{2} G_{N}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=6 \log \left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2^{N}}\right)+G_{N}^{1}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)
$$

where $\left\|G_{N}^{1}\right\|_{L^{\infty}(B(0 ; 2))} \leq C_{2}$.
Eventually, it yields that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|f_{N}(\cdot)\right\|_{W^{1, \infty}} \leq c,\left\|f_{N}(\cdot)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{2}}} \leq c(\log N)^{\frac{1}{2}},\left\|f_{N}(\cdot)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{2}+1}} \leq c N \\
\left\|g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \nabla^{\perp} f_{N}(\mathbf{x})\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)} \geq c_{1} N
\end{gathered}
$$

with $2<p<\infty$ and $c, c_{1}$ are independent of $x_{0}, y_{0}$ and $N$. More details refer to Lemma 3.1. Accordingly,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\eta_{0}(\cdot)\right\|_{W^{1, \infty}} \leq \frac{c}{\sqrt{N}},\left\|\eta_{0}(\cdot)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{2}}} \leq \frac{c(\log N)^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\sqrt{N}},\left\|\eta_{0}(\cdot)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{2}+1}} \leq c \sqrt{N} \\
\left\|g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \nabla^{\perp} \eta_{0}(\mathbf{x})\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)} \geq c_{1} \sqrt{N}
\end{gathered}
$$

# Step 3. Lower bound estimation of $\|\nabla \eta\|_{L^{\infty}}$. 

To obtain the lower bound estimate for $\|\nabla \eta\|_{L^{\infty}}$, we apply $\nabla^{\perp}$ to both sides of $(1.2)_{1}$ instead of $\nabla$. This is mainly due to the fact that the Biot-Savart law governing the velocity field $u$ involves the gradient $\nabla^{\perp}$, applying $\nabla^{\perp}$ makes the equation more concise.

As a result, denote $\Theta=\nabla^{\perp} \eta$, then $\Theta$ satisfies

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\partial_{t} \Theta+u \cdot \nabla \Theta=-g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \Theta-\left(\nabla^{\perp} g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta+\Theta \cdot \nabla u \\
u=(-\Delta)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathcal{R}_{1} \Theta \\
\Theta(\mathbf{x}, 0)=\Theta_{0}=\nabla^{\perp} \eta_{0}(\mathbf{x})
\end{array}\right.
$$

Compounding on both sides of $(1.3)_{1}$ the Lagrangian flow-map $\Phi$ transported by the velocity $u$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{t}(\Theta \circ \Phi)+ & g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(\Theta \circ \Phi) \\
= & \left(-g^{\prime} \circ \Phi\right)\left[\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}, \Phi\right] \Theta+\left(g^{\prime}-g^{\prime} \circ \Phi\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(\Theta \circ \Phi) \\
& +\left(\Theta \cdot \nabla u-\left(\nabla^{\perp} g^{\prime}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta\right) \circ \Phi
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\left[\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}, \Phi\right] \Theta=\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(\Theta) \circ \Phi-\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(\Theta \circ \Phi)
$$

By Duhamel's principle,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Theta \circ \Phi=\mathrm{e}^{-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} t} \Theta_{0} & +\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(t-\tau)}\left(-g^{\prime} \circ \Phi\right)\left[\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}, \Phi\right] \Theta(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau \\
& +\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(t-\tau)}\left(\left(g^{\prime}-g^{\prime} \circ \Phi\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(\Theta \circ \Phi)\right)(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau \\
& +\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2}(t-\tau)}\left(\left(\Theta \cdot \nabla u-\left(\nabla^{\perp} g^{\prime}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta\right) \circ \Phi\right)(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

In fact, we can obtain the following lower bound estimate (see Section 4.1 for more details)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\Theta\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq t & \left\|-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \Theta_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}-\left\|\Theta_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}-C t^{2}\left\|\Theta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \\
& -C t^{2}\|\nabla u\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\left(1+\mathrm{e}^{2 t\|\nabla u\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}}\right)\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \\
& -C t\left(1+\mathrm{e}^{2 t\|\nabla u\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}}\right)\left(\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}}+\|\eta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}$ and $L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}$ represent $L^{\infty}\left([0, t] ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)\right)$ and $L^{\infty}\left([0, t] ; B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)\right)$, respectively.

Recall the special $\eta_{0}$ constructed in Step 2 and the prior estimates in Step 1, and we are able to get

$$
\|\Theta\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq \frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{2} t \sqrt{N}-\bar{c}_{2} t^{2} N-\bar{c}_{3} t \sqrt{N}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}
$$

by choosing $t$ sufficiently small and $N$ sufficiently large. It follows by the continuity method that for sufficiently small $t \sim \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}$,

$$
\|\Theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq \tilde{C}
$$

See a detailed explanation in Section 5.2.
The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 provides a list of lemmas to be used in the proofs of the theorem stated above and the propositions below. Section 3 presents a detailed construction of a sequence of functions with special properties. The construction of the initial data in the proof of Theorem 1.1 makes use of this special sequence. In Section 4, we briefly describe the local existence and uniqueness of the IPM equation and establish two key local priori bounds. Section 5 is divided into two parts. Subsection 5.1 is devoted to obtaining a lower bound estimate for $\nabla \eta$ and subsection 5.2 is devoted to proving Theorem 1.1.

# Notations: 

- In the following, we use $C$ to denote various constants whose values may be different from line to line. Occasionally, we use $c$ (or $c$ with a subindex) to mark some crucial constants.
- For notational simplicity, throughout this paper we adopt the following convention unless otherwise specified:

1. In Section 2 (Preliminaries) and the Appendix: $\|f\|_{X}$ denotes $\|f\|_{X\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}$,
2. In all other Sections: $\|f\|_{X}$ denotes $\|f\|_{X\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)}$.

Here, $X$ may denote any of these function spaces: homogeneous Besov space $\dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}$, nonhomogeneous Besov space $B_{p, r}^{s}$, Lebesgue space $L^{p}$, or Sobolev space $W^{s, p}$.

## 2 Preliminaries
### 2.1 Key analytical estimates on Besov spaces

For the definition and basic properties of Besov spaces, we refer to Appendix A.
In what follows, we shall establish a logarithmic-type inequality characterizing the difference between the homogeneous Besov spaces $\dot{B}_{p, r_{1}}^{s}$ and $\dot{B}_{p, r_{2}}^{s}$. This result will be particularly useful for estimating the function $f_{N}$ in Besov spaces in Proposition 3.1.
Lemma 2.1. There exists a constant $C>0$ such that for all $s \in \mathbb{R}, \nu>0, n \geq 2,1 \leq$ $r_{1} \leq \min \left\{r_{2}, r_{3}\right\}$ and $1 \leq p \leq \infty$,
$\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{1}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leq C \frac{1+\nu}{\nu}\left(1+\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{2}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\left[\log _{2}\left(\mathrm{e}+\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}+\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{s+\nu}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\right)\right]^{\frac{1}{r_{1}}-\frac{1}{r_{2}}}\right)$.

Proof. Using the definition of homogeneous Besov norms, we decompose the norm into three parts:

$$
\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{1}}^{r_{1}}}^{r_{1}}=\underbrace{\sum_{k \leq-\sigma}\left(2^{k s}\left\|\dot{\Delta}_{k} f\right\|_{L^{p}}\right)^{r_{1}}}_{I_{1}}+\underbrace{\sum_{|k|<\sigma}\left(2^{k s}\left\|\dot{\Delta}_{k} f\right\|_{L^{p}}\right)^{r_{1}}}_{I_{2}}+\underbrace{\sum_{k \geq \sigma}\left(2^{k s}\left\|\dot{\Delta}_{k} f\right\|_{L^{p}}\right)^{r_{1}}}_{I_{3}}
$$

where $\sigma>0$ will be chosen later.
Estimate of $I_{2}$ : By Hölder's inequality with exponents $\frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}}$ and $\frac{r_{2}}{r_{2}-r_{1}}$, we obtain:

$$
I_{2} \leq(2 \sigma-1)^{\frac{r_{2}-r_{1}}{r_{2}}}\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{2}}^{r_{1}}}^{r_{1}}
$$

Estimate of $I_{1}$ and $I_{3}$ : For any $\nu>0$, we have

$$
I_{1} \leq\left(\sum_{k \leq-\sigma} 2^{k \nu \frac{r_{1} r_{3}}{r_{3}-r_{1}}}\right)^{\frac{r_{3}-r_{1}}{r_{3}}}\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}^{r_{1}} \leq \frac{2^{-\sigma \nu r_{1}}}{\left(1-2^{-\nu \frac{r_{1} r_{3}}{r_{3}-r_{1}}}\right)^{\frac{r_{3}-r_{1}}{r_{3}}}}\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}^{r_{1}}
$$

Similarly,

$$
I_{3} \leq \frac{2^{-\sigma \nu r_{1}}}{\left(1-2^{-\nu \frac{r_{1} r_{3}}{r_{3}-r_{1}}}\right)^{\frac{r_{3}-r_{1}}{r_{3}}}}\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}^{r_{1}}
$$

By combining these estimates, we get

$$
\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{1}}^{r_{1}}} \leq(2 \sigma-1)^{\frac{r_{2}-r_{1}}{r_{1} r_{2}}}\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{2}}^{r_{2}}}+\frac{2^{-\sigma \nu}}{\left(1-2^{-\nu \frac{r_{1} r_{3}}{r_{3}-r_{1}}}\right)^{\frac{r_{2}-r_{1}}{r_{1} r_{3}}}}\left(\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}+\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}\right)
$$

Choosing $\sigma$ being a closest positive integer to $\frac{1}{\nu} \log _{2}\left(\mathrm{e}+\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}+\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r_{3}}^{r_{1}}}\right)$ yields $(2.1)$.

At the conclusion of this subsection, we recall an important commutator estimate and establish two key product estimates. The first estimate concerns a function interacting with a classical Riesz operator, while the second deals with a function that requires no integration.

Lemma 2.2 ([17]). Let $n \geq 2$ and $\mathcal{R}$ be a Riesz operator, the following estimate are valid,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathcal{R}(f g)-\mathcal{R}(f) g\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} & \leq C\|f\|_{B M O\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\|g\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \leq C\|f\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\|g\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $1<p<\infty$ and $C$ depends only on $p, n$.

Lemma 2.3. Let $n \geq 2,1 \leq p<\infty$ and $s>0$. Let $\mathcal{R}$ be a Riesz operator, the following estimates hold, for any functions $f, g \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \cap B_{p, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$

$$
\|f \mathcal{R} g\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leq C\left(\|f\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\|g\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}+\|g\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\|f\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\right)
$$

and

$$
\|f g\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leq C\left(\|f\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\|g\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}+\|g\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\|f\|_{B_{m, 1}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\right)
$$

Proof. By Bony's decomposition, we have

$$

\end{aligned}

$$
\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}

& \leq C\|g\|_{L^{\infty}}\|f\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s}}
\end{aligned}

$$

$$

\begin{aligned}
\|(\Theta \cdot \nabla u)(\tau)\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}} & =\left\|\Theta \cdot \mathcal{R} \mathcal{R}_{1} \Theta(\tau)\right\|_{\tilde{B}_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}} \\
& \leq C\|\Theta(\tau)\|_{L^{\infty}}\|\Theta(\tau)\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using (2.3) and Lemma A. 2 again gives to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\nabla^{\perp} g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta(\tau)\right\|_{\tilde{B}_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}} & \leq\left\|g^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta(\tau)\right\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}} \\
& \leq C\left\|g^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{2}\right)\right\|_{B_{\infty, 1}^{\hat{g}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)}\left\|\mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta(\tau)\right\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}} \\
& \leq C\left\|g^{\prime}\right\|_{W^{2, \infty}(\mathbb{R})}\|\eta(\tau)\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}} \leq C\|\eta(\tau)\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

By combining the estimates (5.8) and (5.9) with Lemma 2.5, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathfrak{B}_{4 \hat{\imath}} & \leq C \int_{0}^{t}\|\nabla \Phi(\tau)\|_{L^{\infty}}^{\frac{2}{\hat{p}}}\left(\|(\Theta \cdot \nabla u)(\tau)\|_{B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}}+\left\|\nabla^{\perp} g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \eta(\tau)\right\|_{\tilde{B}_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \\
& \leq C t \mathrm{e}^{\frac{2}{p} t\|\nabla u\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}}\left(\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} \tilde{B}_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}}+\|\eta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{\hat{p}, 1}^{\hat{g}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we ultimately obtain

$$
\mathfrak{B}_{4} \leq C t\left(1+\mathrm{e}^{\frac{2}{p} t\left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}}\right)\left(\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}}+\|\eta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}}\right)
$$

By incorporating the estimates for $\mathfrak{B}_{1}-\mathfrak{B}_{4}$ into (5.1), we derive a lower bound estimate for $\|\Theta\|_{L^{\infty}}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\Theta\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq & t\left\|-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \Theta_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}-\left\|\Theta_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}-C t^{2}\left\|\Theta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \\
& -C t^{2}\left(\|u\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}+\|\nabla u\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\right)\left(1+\mathrm{e}^{2 t\left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}}\right)\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \\
& -C t\left(1+\mathrm{e}^{2 t\left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}}\right)\left(\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}}+\|\eta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This establishes (5.2) and consequently completes the proof of the lemma.

# 5.2 Conclusion of the Proof 

Proof of Theorem 1.1. We initialize the perturbation as

$$
\eta_{0}(\mathbf{x})=\rho_{0}(\mathbf{x})-g\left(x_{2}\right)=\frac{f_{N}}{\sqrt{N}} \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)
$$

where $f_{N}$ is constructed via Proposition 3.1. Given that $g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right) \not \equiv 0$, we choose $h(\mathbf{x})=g^{\prime}\left(x_{2}\right)$ (depending only on $x_{2}$ ) in accordance with Proposition 3.1, thereby obtaining the crucial estimates

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\eta_{0}(\cdot)\right\|_{W^{1, \infty}} \leq \frac{c}{\sqrt{N}},\left\|\eta_{0}(\cdot)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \leq \frac{c(\log N)^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\sqrt{N}},\left\|\eta_{0}(\cdot)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}} \leq c \sqrt{N} \\
\left\|g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \nabla^{\perp} \eta_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq c_{1} \sqrt{N}
\end{gathered}
$$

where the constants $c, c_{1}>0$ are independent of $N$.
By applying Proposition 4.2 together with (5.10), we obtain, for sufficiently small $t>0$,

$$
\|\eta(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}} \leq \frac{\frac{c_{g}}{2}+2\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}}}{1-C\left(\frac{c_{g}}{2}+2\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}}}\right) t} \leq c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\eta(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} & \leq\left\|\eta_{0}\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \mathrm{e}^{C t}\left(\sup _{0 \leq s \leq t}\|\eta(s)\|_{B^{\frac{2}{p}+1} a_{p, 1}}+c_{g}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{(\log N)^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\sqrt{N}} \mathrm{e}^{t\left(c_{4} \sqrt{N}+c_{5}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The continuous embedding $B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}} \hookrightarrow L^{\infty}$ and $L^{p}$ - boundedness of the Riesz operator gives, for all $t>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|u(t)\|_{L^{\infty}},\|\nabla u(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} \leq\|u(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}} \leq C\|\eta(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}} \leq c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3} \\
& \left.\|\Theta(t)\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}}} \leq C\right\rvert\, \eta(t)\right\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\frac{2}{p}+1}} \leq c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, by (5.11), we have

$$
\left\|-g^{\prime} \mathcal{R}_{1}^{2} \Theta_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq c_{1} \sqrt{N}
$$

Now, substituting these estimates into (5.2), we obtain the lower bound:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\Theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty} \geq} & c_{1} t \sqrt{N}-\frac{c}{\sqrt{N}}-c t^{2} \sqrt{N} \\
& -t^{2}\left(c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}\right)\left(1+e^{2 t\left(c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}\right)}\right)\left(c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}\right) \\
& -t\left(1+e^{2 t\left(c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}\right)}\right) \\
& \times\left(\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}\left(c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}\right)+\frac{(\log N)^{1 / 2}}{\sqrt{N}} e^{t\left(c_{4} \sqrt{N}+c_{5}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We select the time scale parameter as

$$
t=\frac{M}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

where the constant $M>0$ will be determined later. Under this choice, we observe that the exponential terms $e^{2 t\left(c_{2} \sqrt{N}+c_{3}\right)}$ and $e^{t\left(c_{4} \sqrt{N}+c_{5}\right)}$ remain uniformly bounded in $N$. Consequently, for sufficiently large $N$, the lower bound estimate (5.12) reduces to the simplified form

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\Theta\|_{L^{\infty} \geq} & \geq c_{1} t \sqrt{N}-\frac{c}{\sqrt{N}}-c t^{2} \sqrt{N}-\bar{c}_{2} t^{2} N \\
& -\bar{c}_{3} t \sqrt{N}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}-c t \frac{(\log N)^{1 / 2}}{\sqrt{N}} \\
& \geq \bar{c}_{1} t \sqrt{N}-\bar{c}_{2} t^{2} N-\bar{c}_{3} t \sqrt{N}\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Without loss of generality, we may assume $\|\Theta\|_{L_{t}^{\infty} L^{\infty}} \leq \frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{2 \bar{c}_{3}}$, since otherwise the desired result follows immediately. Under this assumption, the simplified bound (5.13) takes the form:

$$
\|\Theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} \geq \frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{2} t \sqrt{N}-\bar{c}_{2} t^{2} N
$$

As a result, by selecting $M=t \sqrt{N}=\frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{4 \bar{c}_{2}}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{0 \leq t \leq \frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{4 \bar{c}_{2} \sqrt{N}}}\|\Theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} & \geq\left|\Theta\left(\frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{4 \bar{c}_{2} \sqrt{N}}\right)\right| \\
& \geq \frac{\bar{c}_{1}^{2}}{16 \bar{c}_{2}}>0
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof is completed by taking $\varepsilon=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}, \tilde{c}=\frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{4 \bar{c}_{2}}$ and $\tilde{C}=\frac{\bar{c}_{1}}{16 \bar{c}_{2}}$.

## A Appendix

In this section, we provide the definitions of the homogeneous and the inhomogeneous Besov spaces. They are defined through the Littlewood-Paley decomposition. Several related embedding relations and inequalities will also be given here. Most of the materials in this section are classical and we refer the reader to the book [1, Chapter 2] for more details.

## A. 1 Littlewood-Paley Decomposition

Consider the annulus $\mathcal{C}:=\left\{\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: \frac{3}{4} \leq|\xi| \leq \frac{8}{3}\right\}$. We can construct radial functions $\chi \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(B\left(0, \frac{4}{3}\right)\right)$ and $\varphi \in C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathcal{C})$, valued in $[0,1]$, that form a partition of unity satisfying

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{j \in \mathbb{Z}} \varphi\left(2^{-j} \xi\right)=1 \quad \forall \xi \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{0\} \\
\chi(\xi)+\sum_{j \geq 0} \varphi\left(2^{-j} \xi\right)=1 \quad \forall \xi \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \\
\operatorname{suup} \varphi\left(2^{-j} \cdot\right) \cap \operatorname{suup} \varphi\left(2^{-j^{\prime}} \cdot\right)=\emptyset, \quad\left|j-j^{\prime}\right| \geq 2 \\
\operatorname{suup} \chi(\cdot) \cap \operatorname{suup} \varphi\left(2^{-j} \cdot\right)=\emptyset, \quad j \geq 1
\end{gathered}
$$

The nonhomogeneous and homogeneous dyadic blocks are defined as follows. For the nonhomogeneous case:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{j} u \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \begin{cases}\varphi\left(2^{-j} D\right) u=2^{j n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} h\left(2^{j} y\right) u(x-y) d y & \text { if } j \geq 0 \\
\chi(D) u=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \tilde{h}(y) u(x-y) d y & \text { if } j=-1 \\
0 & \text { if } j \leq-2\end{cases} \\
& \mathcal{S}_{j} u=\chi\left(2^{-j} D\right) u=2^{j n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \tilde{h}\left(2^{j} y\right) u(x-y) d y, \quad j \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

and for the homogeneous case:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\Delta}_{j} u \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \varphi\left(2^{-j} D\right) u & =2^{j n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} h\left(2^{j} y\right) u(x-y) d y \quad \text { for } j \in \mathbb{Z} \\
\dot{\mathcal{S}}_{j} u & =\chi\left(2^{-j} D\right) u, \quad j \in \mathbb{Z}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $h=\mathscr{F}^{-1} \varphi$ and $\tilde{h}=\mathscr{F}^{-1} \chi$ denote the inverse Fourier transforms of the chosen smooth functions $\varphi$ and $\chi$ respectively. It is straightforward to derive that the lowfrequency cut-off operators $\mathcal{S}_{j}\left(\dot{\mathcal{S}}_{j}\right)$ are also given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{S}_{j} u=\sum_{\ell \leq j-1} \Delta_{\ell} u, \forall u \in \mathcal{S}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \\
& \dot{\mathcal{S}}_{j} u=\sum_{\ell \leq j-1} \dot{\Delta}_{\ell} u, \forall u \in \mathcal{S}_{h}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right):=\mathcal{S}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) / \wp\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\wp\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ denotes the space of polynomials. The operators $\Delta_{j}\left(\dot{\Delta}_{j}\right), \mathcal{S}_{j}\left(\dot{\mathcal{S}}_{j}\right)$ are $(p, p)$-bounded uniformly in $j$. This fact will be consistently used throughout our analysis.

# A. 2 Besov Spaces 

Definition A. 1 (Homogeneous Besov Space). For $s \in \mathbb{R}$ and $1 \leq p, r \leq \infty$, the homogeneous Besov space $\dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}$ consists of all tempered distributions $u \in \mathcal{S}_{h}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ such that

$$
\|u\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}}:=\left\|\left(2^{j s}\left\|\dot{\Delta}_{j} u\right\|_{L^{p}}\right)_{j \in \mathbb{Z}}\right\|_{\ell^{r}(\mathbb{Z})}<\infty
$$

Definition A. 2 (Nonhomogeneous Besov Space). For $s \in \mathbb{R}$ and $1 \leq p, r \leq \infty$, the nonhomogeneous Besov space $B_{p, r}^{s}$ consists of all tempered distributions $u \in \mathcal{S}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ such that

$$
\|u\|_{B_{p, r}^{s}}:=\left\|\left(2^{j s}\left\|\Delta_{j} u\right\|_{L^{p}}\right)_{j \in \mathbb{Z}}\right\|_{\ell^{r}(\mathbb{Z})}<\infty
$$

Many frequently used function spaces are special cases of Besov spaces. The following lemma lists some useful equivalence and embedding relations.

Lemma A.1. For all $s \in \mathbb{R}, H^{s} \sim B_{2,2}^{s}, \dot{H}^{s} \sim \dot{B}_{2,2}^{s}$. For all $s \in \mathbb{R}, W^{s, \infty} \hookrightarrow B_{\infty, \infty}^{s}$.
The Besov spaces defined above obey various inclusion relations. In particular, we have the following lemmas.

Lemma A.2. Assume that $s \in \mathbb{R}$ and $p, r \in[1, \infty]$.
(1) If $s>0$, then

$$
\begin{gathered}
B_{p, r}^{s} \hookrightarrow \dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}, \quad p<\infty \\
B_{\infty, r}^{s} \cap \mathcal{S}_{h}^{\prime} \hookrightarrow \dot{B}_{\infty, r}^{s}
\end{gathered}
$$

(2) If $s_{1} \leq s_{2}$, then $B_{p, r}^{s_{2}} \hookrightarrow B_{p, r}^{s_{1}}$. This inclusion relation is false for the homogeneous Besov spaces.
(3) Besov embedding properties: If $1 \leq p \leq \widetilde{p} \leq \infty, 1 \leq r \leq \widetilde{r} \leq \infty$, then, for any $s \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
B_{p, r}^{s} & \hookrightarrow B_{\widetilde{p}, \widetilde{r}}^{s-n(1 / p-1 / \widetilde{p})} \\
B_{p, 1}^{n / p} & \hookrightarrow L^{\infty}
\end{aligned}
$$

(4) Interpolation inequalities: Assume that $s_{1}<s_{2}, 1 \leq p \leq \infty, 1 \leq r \leq \infty$ and $0<\theta<1$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|u\|_{B_{p, 1}^{s_{1}+(1-\theta) s_{2}}} \leq\|u\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\sigma}}^{\theta}\|u\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r}^{\sigma}}^{1-\theta} \\
& \|u\|_{B_{p, 1}^{\theta s_{1}+(1-\theta) s_{2}}} \leq \frac{C}{s_{2}-s_{1}}\left(\frac{1}{\theta}+\frac{1}{1-\theta}\right)\|u\|_{B_{p, \infty}^{\theta}}^{\theta}\|u\|_{B_{p, \infty}^{s_{2}}}^{1-\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma A.3. Let $K \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be compact. For $s>0$, the spaces $B_{p, r}^{s}(K)$ and $\dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}(K)$ coincide. Moreover, there exists $C>0$ such that for any $f \in \dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}(K)$,

$$
\|f\|_{B_{p, r}^{s}(K)} \leq C(1+|K|)^{s / n}\|f\|_{\dot{B}_{p, r}^{s}(K)}
$$

# A. 3 Nonhomogeneous Bony Decomposition 

In this subsection, we recall nonhomogeneous Bony decomposition:

$$
u v=T_{u} v+T_{v} u+R(u, v)
$$

with nonhomogeneous paraproduct of $v$ by $u$

$$
T_{u} v:=\sum_{j \geq-1} S_{j-1} u \Delta_{j} v
$$

and nonhomogeneous remainder of $u$ and $v$

$$
R(u, v):=\sum_{|j-k| \leq 1} \Delta_{j} u \Delta_{k} v
$$

Lemma A.4. There exist constants $C>0$, such that for any $s, s_{1}, s_{2} \in \mathbb{R}$, and $1 \leq p, p_{1}, p_{2}, r, r_{1}, r_{2} \leq \infty$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|T_{u} v\right\|_{B_{\bar{p}, r}^{s}} \leq C^{|s|+1}\|u\|_{L^{\infty}}\|v\|_{B_{\bar{p}, r}^{s}} \\
\left\|R_{u} v\right\|_{B_{\bar{p}, r}^{s}} \leq \frac{C^{\left|s_{1}+s_{2}\right|+1}}{s_{1}+s_{2}}\|u\|_{B_{p_{1}, r_{1}}^{s_{1}}}\|v\|_{B_{p_{2}, r_{2}}^{s_{2}}}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $s_{1}+s_{2}>0, \frac{1}{p} \leq \frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}} \leq 1, \frac{1}{r_{1}}+\frac{1}{r_{2}}=\frac{1}{r} \leq 1, \bar{s}-\frac{n}{p}=s_{1}-\frac{n}{p_{1}}+s_{2}-\frac{n}{p_{2}}$.

# A. 4 Commutator Estimates 

The following estimates are crucial for handling nonlinear terms in our analysis of system (1.2).

Lemma A.5. Let $\sigma \in \mathbb{R}, 1 \leq r \leq \infty, 1 \leq p \leq p_{1} \leq \infty$, and let $v$ be a vector field on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Assume either:

$$
\sigma>-n \min \left\{\frac{1}{p_{1}}, \frac{1}{p^{\prime}}\right\}
$$

or, in the divergence-free case $(\nabla \cdot v=0)$ :

$$
\sigma>-1-n \min \left\{\frac{1}{p_{1}}, \frac{1}{p^{\prime}}\right\}
$$

where $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{p^{\prime}}=1$. Define the commutator $R_{j}:=\left[v \cdot \nabla, \Delta_{j}\right] f$. Then there exists $C=C\left(p, p_{1}, \sigma, n\right)>0$ such that:

$$
\left\|\left(2^{j \sigma}\left\|R_{j}\right\|_{L^{p}}\right)_{j}\right\|_{C} \leq \begin{cases}C\|\nabla v\|_{B_{p_{1}, \infty}^{\frac{n}{p}} \cap L^{\infty}}\|f\|_{B_{\bar{p}, r}^{s}}, & \text { if } \sigma<1+\frac{n}{p_{1}} \\ C\|\nabla v\|_{B_{p_{1}, \gamma}^{\sigma}}\|f\|_{B_{\bar{p}, r}^{\sigma}}, & \text { if } \sigma>1+\frac{n}{p_{1}} \text { or } \sigma=1+\frac{n}{p_{1}}, r=1\end{cases}
$$

where $\left[v \cdot \nabla, \Delta_{j}\right] f=v \cdot \nabla\left(\Delta_{j} f\right)-\Delta_{j}(v \cdot \nabla f)$.

abstract:
In this paper, we establish the mild ill-posedness of 2D IPM equation in the
critical Sobolev space $W^{1,\infty}$ when the initial data are small
perturbations of stable profile $g(x_2).$ Consequently, instability can be
inferred. Notably, our results are valid for arbitrary vertically stratified
density profiles $g(x_2)$ without imposing any restrictions on the sign of
$g'(x_2).$ From a physical perspective, since gravity acts downward, density
profiles satisfying $g'(x_2) < 0$ typically correspond to stable
configurations, whereas those with $g '(x_2) > 0$ are generally expected to be
unstable. Surprisingly, our analysis uncovers an unexpected instability even
when $g'(x_2) < 0$ and $g'(x_2)\in W^{2,\infty}(\mathbb{R})$. To the best of
our knowledge, this work provides the first rigorous demonstration of IPM
instability for vertically nonlinear density profiles, marking a significant
departure from conventional physical expectations.
